channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: Palestinians Aim for ‘Nonmember State’ Status at United Nations General Assembly
item.description: Palestinians are returning to the General Assembly next week seeking largely symbolic “nonmember state” status, lamenting a “lost year” of no peace talks, expanding Israeli settlements and deteriorating economic conditions.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Obama’s Evolution to a Tougher Line on China
item.description: China has suddenly become a focal point in the presidential campaign, one that encompasses both security and economic concerns and puts to the test the president’s management of the complex relationship.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: As President Obama, pictured here at a town hall meeting in Shanghai in 2009, runs for re-election, his tougher line toward Beijing is showing itself on several fronts.

item.title: The Lede Blog: On a Military Base in Afghanistan, a Surprise Delivery
item.description: A young British soldier suddenly gave birth at the Camp Bastion military post this week, apparently not even knowing that she was pregnant.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: For the Euro, a Costly Shelter From the Storm
item.description: The European Central Bank's new headquarters reflect stability for the common currency but lack the austerity the bank preaches to countries like Greece and Spain.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: Heavy Casualties Reported in Syria Warplane Attack
item.description: At least 30 people, and as many as 100, were killed in Syria on Thursday in the northern Raqqa Province, when government warplanes bombed a gasoline station crowded with people, according to activist groups.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Forces loyal to Syria's president, Bashar al-Assad, are seen in the city of Aleppo on Thursday.

item.title: Lens Blog: Steve Winter's Photographs of Tigers
item.description: Steve Winter has been photographing tigers and other animals for years, but his aim is to pull back the curtain on an idealized — often cutesy — world presented by most wildlife photography.
item.category: International Union for the Conservation of Nature
item.dc:creator: By PETER MOSKOWITZ

item.title: The Lede Blog: Cairo's Graffiti Revolutionaries Reclaim Wall
item.description: After the authorities in Cairo painted over a graffiti mural dedicated to the martyrs of the Egyptian revolution this week, the city's street artists struck back, beginning a new mural on the same wall.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Haim Hefer, Israeli Songwriter and Poet, Dies at 86
item.description: Mr. Hefer, who could be an acerbic critic of Israeli political leaders, helped forge a national identity in contemporary Hebrew with his lyrics and newspaper columns written in verse.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: U.N. Presses Pakistan on Disappearances
item.description: A delegation met with Pakistani government officials and relatives of hundreds of people who have disappeared into the illegal custody of the country’s powerful intelligence and law enforcement agencies over the last decade.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Assault on Consulate in Libya a ‘Terrorist Attack,’ White House Says
item.description: The White House, after Republican criticism, said it was “self-evident” that last week’s assault on the American diplomatic facility in Benghazi, Libya, was a “terrorist attack.”
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Benghazi after the Sept. 11 attack.

item.title: Rubén Zuno Arce, Guilty in Drug Killing, Dies at 82
item.description: Mr. Zuno was a central defendant in the 1985 torture and killing of Enrique Camarena Salazar, an American drug enforcement agent, in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: Santiago Carrillo, Spanish Communist Leader, Dies at 97
item.description: Mr. Carrillo fought Gen. Francisco Franco’s fascist forces during the Spanish Civil War, and later promoted a new, more moderate Communism.
item.dc:creator: By LESLIE KAUFMAN
item.media:description: Santiago Carrillo at the Lower House of the Spanish Parliament in July 1977.

item.title: Restrictions on Religion Are Tightening, Study Finds
item.description: Government restrictions on religion around the world were highest in the Middle East and North Africa, particularly in the period before the Arab Spring uprisings, a Pew study found.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: British Government Blocks Disclosure of Dissident’s Alleged Spy Links
item.description: Lawyers at a hearing on the death of the poisoned Russian whistle-blower Alexander V. Litvinenko said the British authorities wanted his possible contacts with MI6 kept quiet.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Marina Litvinenko, the widow of Alexander V. Litvinenko, left a preliminary hearing in London on Thursday.

item.title: Ex-Commander in Afghanistan in Line for Top Africa Post
item.description: In the wake of the Arab Spring, the Africa Command is seen as one of the most challenging theaters of operation.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and THOM SHANKER

item.title: In China, Panetta Says U.S. Focus on Asia Is No Threat
item.description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta declared Wednesday that the United States was not trying to contain a rising China.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense Leon E. Panetta ate lunch with cadets on Wednesday at a People’s Liberation Army academy in Beijing.

item.title: Marseille Journal: Marseille Hit by Violent Wave of Drug Crimes
item.description: In Marseille, where 20 people have been killed in the last nine months, drug dealers have begun using combat weapons to defend their territory.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:credit: France Keyser for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flowers around a light pole where Walid Marzouki, whom the police suspected of being a drug dealer, was killed.

item.title: Wen Chides Europe on Arms Sale Embargo
item.description: Prime Minister Wen Jiabao said that China would help the European Union recover from crisis even as he criticized the bloc for keeping the embargo.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Premier Wen Jiabao spoke at a summit of European Union and Chinese leaders in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Names of the Dead
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,104 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: British Regulator Declares BSkyB ‘Fit and Proper’
item.description: The announcement about Britain’s biggest satellite pay-TV group, British Sky Broadcasting, offered a victory for its largest shareholder, Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Japan Backs Off Goal to Phase Out Nuclear Power by 2040
item.description: Japan’s reversal on a plan to eliminate its use of nuclear power came after intense opposition from business groups and communities that host the country’s nuclear plants.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: A reactor building at the Fukushima Daiichi plant. The disaster there prompted intense debate on Japan’s use of nuclear power.

item.title: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi of Myanmar Meets Obama
item.description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi called for sanctions against Myanmar to be eased, saying they had served their purpose.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Obama met with Myanmar’s opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, in the Oval Office at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Arctic Sea Ice Stops Melting, but Record Low Is Set
item.description: The apparent low point for 2012 was reached Sunday, when sea ice covered 24 percent of the surface of the Arctic Ocean, down from the previous low of 29 percent set in 2007.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the east coast of Greenland, where the ice sheet meets the sea.

item.title: Trial Implicates Bo Xilai in Heywood Cover-up
item.description: In an official account Wang Lijun, a former police chief, essentially accused the disgraced politician Bo Xilai of trying to cover up the murder of a British businessman by his wife.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The former police chief Wang Lijun essentially accused Bo Xilai of trying to cover up the murder of Neil Heywood.

item.title: French Newspaper Publishes Cartoons Mocking Muhammad
item.description: France planned to close its embassies in 20 countries on Friday after illustrations in a satirical magazine set off new outrage by Muslims.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE and NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: Stéphane Charbonnier, the editorial director of the satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo, spoke to reporters on Wednesday in Paris.
